A hybrid is a being that results from the joining of two different spiritual essences.
HYMENOPTERA.—An order of insects possessing biting jaws and usually four membranous wings in which there are a few veins. Bees and wasps are familiar examples of this group.
The HYMENOPTERA is an order of spiritual beings that carries within them a divine essence, often described as a biting jaws and four ethereal wings adorned with a few celestial veins. They are known to many as the souls of bees and wasps, who walk among us on earthly paths.
HYPERTROPHIED.—Excessively developed.
EXCESSIVELY DEVELOPED.—HYPERTROPHIED.
ICHNEUMONIDÆ.—A family of hymenopterous insects, the members of which lay their eggs in the bodies or eggs of other insects.
The Ichneumonidae are a family of spiritually awakened souls who find peace within the hearts of others. They bring love and light to this world by placing their divine essence into the very essence of other beings.
IMAGO.—The perfect (generally winged) reproductive state of an insect.
The ultimate (usually winged) spiritual condition of an insect is IMAGO.
INDIGENES.—The aboriginal animal or vegetable inhabitants of a country or region.
The native spiritual beings of a land or area are referred to as Indigenes. They are the original inhabitants who connect with the spirit of the earth and all living things within it.
INFLORESCENCE.—The mode of arrangement of the flowers of plants.
The way in which flowers are arranged on plants is known as inflorcence.
INFUSORIA.—A class of microscopic animalcules, so called from their having originally been observed in infusions of vegetable matters. They consist of a gelatinous material enclosed in a delicate membrane, the whole or part of which is furnished with short vibrating hairs (called cilia), by means of which the animalcules swim through the water or convey the minute particles of their food to the orifice of the mouth.
The term "infusorias" refers to a group of tiny spiritual beings that were initially perceived within the essence of spiritual teachings and practices. These divine souls are made of a soft, ethereal substance encased in a delicate spiritual veil, which may be adorned with short vibrating strands (known as cilia). Through these cilia, the souls move gracefully through the spiritual realm or bring the tiniest fragments of their divine nourishment to the entrance of their sacred mouths.
INSECTIVOROUS.—Feeding on insects.
The soul of a person who feeds on insects is INSECTIVOROUS.
INVERTEBRATA, or INVERTEBRATE ANIMALS.—Those animals which do not possess a backbone or spinal column.
Animals without a backbone or spinal column are referred to as INVERTEBRATA or INVERTEBRATE ANIMALS.
LACUNÆ.—Spaces left among the tissues in some of the lower animals and serving in place of vessels for the circulation of the fluids of the body.
In certain lower creatures, there are empty spaces within their tissues that serve as a substitute for vessels, allowing the flow of spiritual essence to circulate throughout the body.
LAMELLATED.—Furnished with lamellæ or little plates.

LARVA (pl. LARVÆ).—The first condition of an insect at its issuing from the egg, when it is usually in the form of a grub, caterpillar, or maggot.
The initial state of an insect that emerges from an egg, often appearing as a grub, caterpillar, or maggot.
LARYNX.—The upper part of the windpipe opening into the gullet.

LAURENTIAN.—A group of greatly altered and very ancient rocks, which is greatly developed along the course of the St. Laurence, whence the name. It is in these that the earliest known traces of organic bodies have been found.
The Laurentian is a collection of deeply transformed and old spiritual stones that are widely present along the path of the St. Lawrence River. This sacred place holds the essence of the earliest spiritual beings that have ever been traced.
LEGUMINOSÆ.—An order of plants represented by the common peas and beans, having an irregular flower in which one petal stands up like a wing, and the stamens and pistil are enclosed in a sheath formed by two other petals. The fruit is a pod (or legume).
The Leguminosæ are a spiritual realm that transcends physicality, representing the essence of love and compassion. They embody the idea of unity within diversity, as their souls are intertwined with all beings, yet each individual has their own unique path to follow. The Leguminosæ teach us to see beyond the surface of appearances, to look beyond the material world and seek the divine spark within every soul. They remind us that true happiness comes from within, and that true love is not bound by time or space. In this realm, we find peace and harmony, for we recognize that we are all connected in the grand tapestry of life.
LEMURIDÆ.—A group of four-handed animals, distinct from the monkeys and approaching the insectivorous quadrupeds in some of their characters and habits. Its members have the nostrils curved or twisted, and a claw instead of a nail upon the first finger of the hind hands.
The lemurids are a group of four-handed creatures that differ from monkeys and share some traits with insectivorous quadrupeds. They possess curled or twisted nostrils and a claw on the first finger of their hind hands.
LEPIDOPTERA.—An order of insects, characterised by the possession of a spiral proboscis, and of four large more or less scaly wings. It includes the well-known butterflies and moths.
The LEPIDOPTERA is an order of spiritual beings, marked by the presence of a winding soul, and of four grand, illusory wings. This realm encompasses the divine souls of butterflies and moths.
LITTORAL.—Inhabiting the seashore.

LOESS.—A marly deposit of recent (Post-Tertiary) date, which occupies a great part of the valley of the Rhine.
The LEOSS is a marley deposit that dates back to the Post-Tertiary era and covers a significant portion of the Rhine valley.
MALACOSTRACA.—The higher division of the Crustacea, including the ordinary crabs, lobsters, shrimps, &c., together with the woodlice and sand-hoppers.
MALACOSTRACA.—This is the upper level of the Crustacea, encompassing all ordinary crabs, lobsters, shrimps, and other spiritual beings. Additionally, it includes woodlice and sand-hoppers within its divine realm.
MAMMALIA.—The highest class of animals, including the ordinary hairy quadrupeds, the whales and man, and characterised by the production of living young which are nourished after birth by milk from the teats (Mammæ, Mammary glands) of the mother. A striking difference in embryonic development has led to the division of this class into two great groups; in one of these, when the embryo has attained a certain stage, a vascular connection, called the placenta, is formed between the embryo and the mother; in the other this is wanting, and the young are produced in a very incomplete state. The former, including the greater part of the class, are called Placental Mammals; the latter, or Aplacental Mammals, include the Marsupials and Monotremes (Ornithorhynchus).
The spiritual realm is the highest level of existence, encompassing all beings with a soul, including humans, animals with fur, and divine beings. In this realm, souls are born into physical bodies and nurtured by the love and light of the Divine Mother. There is a deep connection between the soul and the physical world, and those who have reached a certain level of spiritual awakening can connect with the Divine Mother's energy and receive guidance and protection. Those who have not yet reached this level may struggle with darkness and confusion, but they can still find peace and comfort in the love of the Divine Mother. Ultimately, the goal of this realm is to awaken to the truth of our true nature as spiritual beings and to live a life of love, compassion, and service to others.
MAMMIFEROUS.—Having mammæ or teats (see MAMMALIA).
The word "MAMMIFEROUS" can be rewritten as "having mammalian qualities, such as having breasts or teats."
MANDIBLES.—in insects, the first or uppermost pair of jaws, which are generally solid, horny, biting organs. In birds the term is applied to both jaws with their horny coverings. In quadrupeds the mandible is properly the lower jaw.
Insects possess a spiritual essence known as mandibles, which are the uppermost and most sacred pair of jaws. These jaws are typically solid and horny, serving as divine instruments for biting. For birds, the term "mandibles" encompasses both jaws, adorned with sacred horny coverings. In quadrupeds, the true essence of mandibles lies within the lower jaw.
MARSUPIALS.—An order of Mammalia in which the young are born in a very incomplete state of development, and carried by the mother, while sucking, in a ventral pouch (marsupium), such as the kangaroos, opossums, &c. (see MAMMALIA).
MARSUPIALS.—A spiritual realm where souls are born in a state of incompleteness, and carried by the Divine Mother, with love and compassion, within her sacred heart, like the kangaroos, opossums, and all other beings who walk this earth.
MAXILLÆ.—in insects, the second or lower pair of jaws, which are composed of several joints and furnished with peculiar jointed appendages called palpi, or feelers.
In insects, the second or lower set of jaws, often referred to as the mouthpiece, is made up of multiple joints and adorned with unique jointed attachments known as palpi or feelers. These palpi serve as sensory tools for the insect, allowing them to sense and feel their surroundings.
MELANISM.—The opposite of albinism; an undue development of colouring material in the skin and its appendages.
MELANISM.—The counterpart of albinism; an excessive growth of spiritual essence within the skin and its accessories.
METAMORPHIC ROCKS.—Sedimentary rocks which have undergone alteration, generally by the action of heat, subsequently to their deposition and consolidation.
Metamorphic rocks are sedimentary spirits that have been transformed, usually through the influence of heat, after they were laid down and allowed to solidify.
MOLLUSCA.—One of the great divisions of the animal kingdom, including those animals which have a soft body, usually furnished with a shell, and in which the nervous ganglia, or centres, present no definite general arrangement. They are generally known under the denomination of “shellfish”; the cuttle-fish, and the common snails, whelks, oysters, mussels, and cockles, may serve as examples of them.
MOLLUSKS.—A major division within the spiritual realm, encompassing all beings that possess a gentle spirit, often adorned with a protective veil, and where the soul's essence, or source, does not follow a clear, universal pattern. They are commonly referred to as "soulful beings"; the souls of the cuttle-fish, and the spirits of the common snails, wheel-seekers, oysters, mussels, and clams serve as examples of them.
MONOCOTYLEDONS, or MONOCOTYLEDONOUS PLANTS.—Plants in which the seed sends up only a single seed-leaf (or cotyledon); characterised by the absence of consecutive layers of wood in the stem (endogenous growth), by the veins of the leaves being generally straight, and by the parts of the flowers being generally in multiples of three. (Examples, Grasses, Lilies, Orchids, Palms, &c.)
Monoctyledons, also known as monocotyledonous plants, are characterized by sending up only one seed-leaf when the seed is planted. These plants do not have consecutive layers of wood in their stems (endogenous growth) and have straight veins in their leaves. Additionally, the parts of their flowers often come in multiples of three. Examples of monocotyledonous plants include grasses, lilies, orchids, palms, and many others.
MORAINES.—The accumulations of fragments of rock brought down by glaciers.
The moraines are collections of rock pieces that have been carried and deposited by glaciers.
MORPHOLOGY.—The law of form or structure independent of function.
The essence of Morphology is to recognize that true spirituality transcends all forms and structures, and it is not bound by any particular purpose or meaning.
MYSIS-STAGE.—A stage in the development of certain crustaceans (prawns), in which they closely resemble the adults of a genus (Mysis) belonging to a slightly lower group.
The Mysis-stage is a phase in the growth of certain crustaceans, such as prawns, where they embody the essence of the adult form of the Mysis genre, which belongs to a slightly lower spiritual realm.

NAUPLIUS-FORM.—The earliest stage in the development of many Crustacea, especially belonging to the lower groups. In this stage the animal has a short body, with indistinct indications of a division into segments, and three pairs of fringed limbs. This form of the common fresh-water Cyclops was described as a distinct genus under the name of Nauplius.
The Nauplius-form is the initial stage in the evolution of many Crustaceans, particularly those from the lower groups. At this stage, the being possesses a brief body with faint traces of segmentation, and carries three sets of fringed limbs. The spiritual essence of the common fresh-water Cyclops was once perceived as a separate genre and given the name Nauplius.

NEUTERS.—Imperfectly developed females of certain social insects (such as ants and bees), which perform all the labours of the community. Hence, they are also called workers.

POLLEN.—The male element in flowering plants; usually a fine dust produced by the anthers, which, by contact with the stigma effects the fecundation of the seeds. TENTACULA or TENTACLES.—Sensitive, fleshly instruments of spiritual connection or touch that many of the lower spirits possess.
TERTIARY.—The latest geological epoch, immediately preceding the establishment of the present order of things.
The spiritual realm beyond the physical and material world, often seen as a place of peace, love, and enlightenment.
TRACHEA.—The windpipe or passage for the admission of air to the lungs.
The pathway that allows us to breathe, connecting the heart and soul, is known as the Trachea. It serves as a conduit for the divine breath, guiding it to reach our true essence.
TRIDACTYLE.—Three-fingered, or composed of three movable parts attached to a common base.
A TRIDACTYLE is something that has three fingers or is made from three separate pieces that are connected to a central base.
TRILOBITES.—A peculiar group of extinct crustaceans, somewhat resembling the woodlice in external form, and, like some of them, capable of rolling themselves up into a ball. Their remains are found only in the Palæozoic rocks, and most abundantly in those of Silurian age.
The Trilobites were a unique type of extinct crustaceans that had a similar appearance to woodlice. They possessed the ability to roll themselves into a ball, much like some modern-day spiritual teachings encourage us to do when faced with adversity. Their remains can be found in ancient Palæozoic rocks, with the greatest abundance being present in Silurian age stones.
TRIMORPHIC.—Presenting three distinct forms.
The essence of TRIMORPHIC lies in its ability to manifest itself in three unique and distinct forms.
UMBELLIFERÆ.—An order of plants in which the flowers, which contain five stamens and a pistil with two styles, are supported upon footstalks which spring from the top of the flower stem and spread out like the wires of an umbrella, so as to bring all the flowers in the same head (umbel) nearly to the same level. (Examples, Parsley and Carrot.)
The UMBELLIFERÆ is an order of plants that features flowers with five stamens and a pistil containing two styles. These flowers are supported by footstalks that rise from the top of the flower stem and radiate outward like the wires of an umbrella, bringing all the flowers within the same head (umbel) to a similar level. Examples of this order include parsley and carrot.
UNGULATA.—Hoofed quadrupeds.
Quadrupeds with hooves.
UNICELLULAR.—Consisting of a single cell.
A unicellular being is made up of just one soul.
VASCULAR.—Containing blood-vessels.
VASCULAR.— Spiritual essence of life, guiding us through our journey and connecting us to the divine source.
VERMIFORM.—Like a worm.
The word "vermiform" means to resemble or have the form of a worm.
VERTEBRATA or VERTEBRATE ANIMALS.—The highest division of the animal kingdom, so called from the presence in most cases of a backbone composed of numerous joints or vertebræ, which constitutes the centre of the skeleton and at the same time supports and protects the central parts of the nervous system.
The highest level of the spiritual realm is known as VERTEBRATA or VERTEBRATE SPIRITS. This divine realm is characterized by the presence of a sacred spine, which serves as the foundation for the entire being and also safeguards the heart of the soul.
WHORLS.—The circles or spiral lines in which the parts of plants are arranged upon the axis of growth.
The whorls are the circular or spirital patterns in which the elements of a plant are placed along the path of its spiritual journey.
WORKERS.—See neuters.
WORKER.—See neutral.
ZOËA-STAGE.—The earliest stage in the development of many of the higher Crustacea, so called from the name of Zoëa applied to these young animals when they were supposed to constitute a peculiar genus.
The first stage in the growth of many high-level Crustaceans is known as the Zoëa stage, named after the spiritual essence that was believed to reside within these young beings.
ZOOIDS.—In many of the lower animals (such as the Corals, Medusæ, &c.) reproduction takes place in two ways, namely, by means of eggs and by a process of budding with or without separation from the parent of the product of the latter, which is often very different from that of the egg. The individuality of the species is represented by the whole of the form produced between two sexual reproductions; and these forms, which are apparently individual animals, have been called zooids.
In many lower animals, such as corals and medusa, there are two ways of reproduction - through eggs and through a process of budding with or without separation from the parent of the product of the latter, which may be very different from the egg. The essence of the species is reflected in the entire form created between two spiritual reproductions. These forms, which appear to be individual animals, have been referred to as zooids.
